conclusion: The graph shows the relationship between position (x) and time (t), with position on the vertical axis and time on the horizontal axis. The graph appears to be linear with a positive slope.

We need to find the car's speed at t = 2 seconds. Speed is the rate of change of position with respect to time, which is the derivative of position with respect to time, or the slope of the position-time graph.
The graph is a straight line, indicating constant acceleration. At t = 0, the position is at 10 m (y-intercept). The line extends backward with a dashed line to t = -2.
The equation of the line can be represented as x = mt + b, where m is the slope (representing speed) and b is the y-intercept. The y-intercept b is 10 (the position at t = 0).

Since the graph is a straight line, the slope of this line represents the constant speed of the vehicle. The speed is constant throughout, so the speed at t = 2 seconds is the same as the slope of the line.
The line appears to have a positive slope, indicating the vehicle is moving in the positive x direction.
The graph rises at a constant rate, but the exact value of the slope cannot be determined from the graph due to the lack of precise markings.

The car's speed at the end of the 2nd second would be equal to the slope of the line shown. However, the graph doesn't provide enough precise markings to determine the exact numerical value of this slope.
